page.title: Overview
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0320.mp3

Audio transcript


For the next part of this unit, we will use a short curriculum on health literacy to demonstrate strategies, tools, and guidelines to integrate digital literacy activities across lessons, units, and curricula. However, the strategies, tools, and guidelines apply equally to any topic or theme.

In this part of the unit, we will examine a variety of lessons in a curriculum and identify the points at which the tasks might be undertaken in a digital context. After identifying the digital tasks, we will examine ways in which to incorporate at least one type of digital task across a short curriculum.

At the end, you will look at a lesson yourself, identify where a digital task is appropriate, and design a digital task to add to the lesson. The final goal is to have at least one digital task to use consistently in each lesson in a unit or course.

page.title: Staying Healthy for Beginners
page.contents:
For this unit, we explore integrating a digital task into a beginning-level curriculum, but the approach described can be integrated into any level of an adult ELA program, depending on the students’ backgrounds and needs. At higher levels, the language will be more complex.

A health theme was selected to illustrate integrating digital literacy into adult education for this unit. We will be looking at the curriculum titled Staying Healthy for Beginners: An English Learner’s Guide to Health Care and Healthy Living. This is five-lesson curriculum is designed for high-beginning adult ELLs.

Florida Literacy Coalition, Inc. (2014). Staying healthy for beginners: an English learner’s guide to health care and healthy living. Orlando, FL: Florida Department of Education, Division of Career and Adult Education. http://floridaliteracy.org/health_literacy_curriculum.html (used with permission).

page.title: Staying Healthy for Beginners: An English Learner’s Guide to Health Care and Healthy Living
page.contents:
The Teacher’s Guide was written by the Florida Literacy Coalition Inc., under subcontract to Kratos Learning, with funding from the U.S. Department of Education, Office of Career, Technical and Adult Education.

The curriculum and associated materials are available at the Florida Literacy Coalition and in the LINCS Resource Collection. The curriculum resources for both teachers and students are freely available online at http://floridaliteracy.org/health_literacy_curriculum.html

Florida Literacy Coalition, Inc. (2014). Staying healthy for beginners: an English learner’s guide to health care and healthy living. Orlando, FL: Florida Department of Education, Division of Career and Adult Education. (used with permission).

page.title: Unit Activity 4, Part 1: Get To Know the Curriculum
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0330.mp3

Audio transcript


Get to know the Staying Healthy curriculum by reading the introduction and information for Chapter 1 in the Teacher’s Guide. In addition, look at Chapter 1 in the Student Book. Notice that each chapter includes a variety of related activities, which would translate into lessons. The next slide has some questions to think about regarding this Staying Healthy curriculum. Then read a teacher’s responses to these same questions.

Look at the Teacher’s Guide. Read the foreword, the introduction, and Chapter 1 to get a feel for the way the guide works, what is included, and what is not.

Teacher’s Guide, pp. iii, 1–11:

http://lincs.ed.gov/publications/pdf/StayingHealthyTeacherGuide2014.pdf

Chapter 1, Student Resource Book, pp. 1–7:

http://floridaliteracy.org/pdf-docs/ch1healthcare.pdf

Notice that each chapter is a set of related lessons.

page.title: Question/Response
page.contents:
1. What do you like about this chapter? 2. In your life, what tasks related to health care are undertaken in a digital environment? 3. What activities could be added or adapted so that learners could work on them digitally?

Florida Literacy Coalition, Inc. (2014). Staying healthy for beginners: an English learner’s guide to health care and healthy living. Orlando, FL: Florida Department of Education, Division of Career and Adult Education. http://floridaliteracy.org/health_literacy_curriculum.html (used with permission)

page.title: Question 1
page.contents:
1. What do you like about this chapter?

I really like this chapter. It includes explicit vocabulary instruction and activities for oral skills as well as written skills; the activities are scaffolded well. The pictures are clear. Some activities will stretch some learners’ abilities (Maria’s Story), and some are easier (practice on p. 6). The lesson includes extra resources in the Teacher Guide (pp. 7–10).

I think that this lesson would work well for many different kinds of students. Depending on the level and how often the class meets, it could take a week or longer.

page.title: Question 2
page.contents:
2. In your life, what tasks related to health care are undertaken in a digital environment?

Increasingly, I need to fill out forms for my doctor online and communicate with my health care providers by e-mail. Sometimes, I have to order prescription refills online and check my test results online.

page.title: Unit Activity: Forms Part 2
page.contents:
Deliver the Online Form to Your Students

Whether students bring their own devices or they are provided in the classroom, a variety of ways exist for you to deliver the online form to your students so that they can fill out the form online.

E-mail: If your students have e-mail accounts, e-mail the form to them. This would work in BYOD contexts and in those contexts for which the program provides the devices.

Document link: Put a link into a document that is on the desktop of the devices that your students will use. This would work in contexts in which you take your students to a computer lab or contexts with classroom sets of devices.

Write the link: This is the least desirable option but can be used if necessary. Pass out small squares of paper on which you have printed the link. Use large print. Ask your students to type the link into a browser.

page.title: How to Make an Online Form to go with Chapter 1: Health Care
page.contents:
Watch this screencast to see how to make an online form with the information from Staying Healthy for Beginners, Chapter 1. If you’d like to read the instructions, a print version is available, as well, at the link provided on the screen.

Download directions here

Tech Tips


Many ways exist for making free online forms. If Google forms are not available to you or if something new and exciting has come along since the creation of this module, feel free to use it. Search for online videos that show you how. Online forms are commonly called online surveys.

page.title: Unit Activity: Forms
page.contents:
Step 1: Following the model demonstrated on the previous page, make an online form to accompany Staying Healthy, Chapter 1.

Step 2: Look at Chapter 2. The action activity on page 15 lends itself to an online form that you might require students to complete online. Use the same process that you used in Part 2 to create an online form.

Make a Google Form

Tech Tips

page.title: Question 3
page.contents:
3. What activities could be added or adapted so that learners can work on them digitally?

I think that I could create an online form that a gives students practice in filling out online forms. It seems to me that the Practice activity on page 6 would lend itself to an easy online form. This is the kind of thing that I have to do online more and more often these days.

page.title: Create a Form for the Remaining Chapters
page.contents:
_√_ Ch. 1: Health Care

_√_ Ch. 2: Doctors

___ Ch. 3: Medicine

___ Ch. 4: Health Food

___ Ch. 5: Staying Healthy

Notice that this form has several new formats, including the date and checkbox lists. Make sure that your students are ready for a new form before introducing new types of question formats.

Tech Tips


The Teacher’s Guide includes several PDF forms that can serve as guides for making online forms. Sample medical forms can be found at http://lincs.ed.gov/health/10_forms.

page.title: Sample Digital Tasks for Other Common Adult ELL Class Topics
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0350.mp3

Audio transcript


Here are some examples of digital tasks that can be integrated into common adult ELA program topics. The digital tasks range in level of difficulty and type of classes for which they are appropriate. Integrating online forms is appropriate in almost every topic. In today’s world, online forms exist in almost every area of life. You will want to make special note about high-stakes online forms. Encourage your students to print out these types of forms and work on them offline to ensure accuracy. Help your students understand that it can be difficult to correct errors on high-stakes forms after they have been submitted.

In the next pages, a set of guidelines will help you design digital tasks. Digital tasks can be part of every topic that you teach in your adult ELA classes, to help your learners develop digital literacy skills to use in the areas of work, education, family, and more.

Topic or theme

Digital task

English language acquisition focus

Children’s education

E-mail the teacher

Use online field trip permission and volunteer applications

Find information on school website*

Communicate informally through writing

Convey personal information

Scan for information

Employment

E-mail cover letter as an attachment

Use online job application forms

Search for a job online*

Communicate formally through writing

Convey personal information

Read carefully for information

Consumer information

Use technical support by chat or e-mail

Complete online forms for product registration or warranty

Compare products using consumer reviews

Communicate informally through writing

Read technical questions for understanding

Read for understanding, synthesize

Community

Locate addresses on map and navigation help

Find ESL classes available or volunteer opportunities*

Read maps for information

Scan for information

Transportation

Find local public transportation system and routes

Find bus/train arrival times

Complete an online credit application for car purchase

Read maps for information

Scan for information

Convey personal information

*Will be discussed in Units 3 and 4

page.title: What do you and others in your community have to do digitally?
page.contents:
Guidelines for Designing Digital Tasks

These guidelines for creating digital tasks apply regardless of the level you teach. From beginning to advanced, all ESL students need the opportunity to engage in language activities in a digital context that approximates what they do (or will) encounter.

For each topic, ask yourself what you and others in your community have to do digitally.

Chances are good that your students also will have to perform the same tasks digitally. For example, in a unit on education, your students are likely to need to read a school calendar, find the class webpage, e-mail the teacher to communicate, and fill out an online form to volunteer for a field trip. Pick one type of digital task and incorporate it into each lesson in that topic, as you did with online forms in Staying Healthy.

page.title: Recognize the importance of Routine
page.contents:
Just as it is important to have routines in the classroom, it also is important to have consistent patterns for the lessons within a unit or a curriculum. Consistent routines make the classroom predictable, so that students’ attention can focus on the new elements, including new information, words, and forms.

Select one type of digital task and then do a version of it with each lesson.

Do the same digital task for each chapter (or unit) so that students become more and more familiar with it. For example, start with simple forms and gradually increase the complexity of the form to include different types of responses (e.g., check boxes, fill in the blank).

page.title: Use the Same Language Used in the Chapter or the Lesson
page.contents: The digital task should use the same words, phrases, sentences, and questions that are used in the lesson. Only the digital format should be new to the students.

page.title: Gradually Change the Format of the Task To Look More Like a Real-World Task
page.contents: In the case of forms, pay attention to the forms that you fill out online and face to face in your own life. As the forms in your class gradually become more complex, make them look more and more like the forms you see in your own life. Chances are good that your students also will need to fill out these kinds of forms.

page.title: Check In With Your Students
page.contents:
Do not assume that your students do (or do not) know how to use technology to accomplish the digital task. Check in with them. This also has the advantage of identifying students who have experience with technology.

Encourage students to share their expertise with technology. Distributed expertise enhances positive interactions to a class community.

page.title: Explain to Your Students That the Digital Task You Are Working on Is Part of Everyday Life
page.contents: It is important for all adults to understand the reasons why they are doing things, especially new and potentially difficult things. Ask your students what they have encountered in their lives. Use examples from your life and the lives of others in your community to show your students the relevance of the digital tasks you are doing. Relevance is very important for adult learners.

page.title: Provide Many Opportunities to Practice
page.contents: In the case of online forms, students can access the form as many times as they like. If they have access to a device with an Internet connection, they can practice at home, at the library, or wherever they access the Internet. Whatever digital task you select, provide many opportunities for practice.

page.title: Expect That There Will Be Problems
page.contents:
Because of the complexity of technology and adults’ varying comfort with it, there will always be problems. Expect them, and teach your students to expect them, as well.

Together with your students, learn a variety of strategies to solve problems. For example, look at all the menu options to see if something sounds potentially helpful, use an Internet browser and the search bar to ask a question, click on all the different icons on the page, and so forth.

Use problems as learning experiences. Of course, there may be a student in your class who knows possible solutions and can be the expert for a specific problem!

page.title: Take Advantage of Expertise in the Classroom
page.contents:
We are all learners in the rapidly-changing digital environment. In your class planning, take advantage of the expertise of your students. It is a good learning experience for them to be an expert on things that the teacher is not an expert in.

When there is digital expertise among the students in your class, have the expert student(s) perform a demonstration for the class or serve as a roving helper, or you can pair up more expert learners with learners who are new to the technology skill. There are many ways to utilize students who are more expert with digital skills, and it benefits all the students to see that expertise.

page.title: Unit Activity
page.contents:
Florida Literacy Coalition, Inc. (2014). Staying healthy for beginners: an English learner’s guide to health care and healthy living. Orlando, FL: Florida Department of Education, Division of Career and Adult Education. http://floridaliteracy.org/health_literacy_curriculum.html (used with permission).

For this activity, we will use the same curriculum that was used in Unit Activity 4: Staying Healthy for Beginners: An English Learner’s Guide to Health Care and Healthy Living.

We are using a health literacy curriculum for this demonstration, but you can use any curriculum to complete Unit Activity 5.

Although the examples that we are using are for beginning and high-beginning adult ELA classes, you can use the same process for higher level classes.

Even though the process is the same, the language of the task (e.g., online form) will be appropriate to the level of the class.

page.title: Identify a Second Digital Task
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0360.mp3

Audio transcript


Earlier in this unit, we identified a variety of tasks related to health care that were often handled digitally. The tasks included filling out online medical forms, ordering prescription refills, checking test results, and communicating with health care providers. Getting information about health issues, information about prescriptions, and information explaining test results are also tasks often accomplished digitally.

In Unit 3 of this module, we will address access to high-quality information online. Increasingly, people are being encouraged to use eHealth portals to do a variety of things related to health, including communicating with health care providers. E-mail is an important element of this. Not only are e-mail conventions used to communicate with providers directly or through an eHealth portal, but an e-mail account is usually required for a user to sign up for the eHealth portal. For many adult ELLs, having an e-mail account and knowing how to use it are very important skills.

Health care tasks that are often performed digitally include the following:

  • Filling out online medical forms

  • Ordering prescription refills

  • Checking tests results

  • Communicating with health care providers

eHealth Portals

  • Are used to do a variety of things related to health (Chapman, Rowe, & Witte, 2010), including communication with health care providers

  • Usually require an e-mail account as part of signup

For many adult ELLs, having an e-mail account and knowing how to use it are very important.

page.title: Getting To Know the Curriculum (Again)
page.contents:
Look at the Teacher’s Guide. Review the foreword, introduction, and Chapter 1.

Teacher’s Guide, pp. iii, 1–11:

http://lincs.ed.gov/publications/pdf/StayingHealthyTeacherGuide2014.pdf

Chapter 1, Student Resource Book, pp. 1–7:

http://floridaliteracy.org/pdf-docs/ch1healthcare.pdf

This time, answer a different question (optional):

What activities could be added or adapted so that learners can do them digitally in an e-mail?

page.title: Integrating E-mail as a Digital Task
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0370.mp3

Audio transcript


On page 5 of the Student Resource Book is a speaking activity in which a patient and a health center worker have a telephone conversation. In the conversation, the patient asks to make an appointment and then describes his or her symptoms. The health center worker then gives the patient an appointment. The same type of communication often occurs by e-mail. This is an opportunity to integrate the digital task of sending an e-mail into Chapter 1. The e-mail on this slide demonstrates several of the guidelines for developing digital tasks: It uses the exact language that is used in the chapter and mirrors the patterns used in the speaking activity. Only the digital format is new to students.

The speaking activity on page 5 of the student resource book contains the following scenarios:

  • A patient and a health center worker have a telephone conversation.

  • The patient asks to make an appointment and then describes his or her symptoms.

  • The health center worker then gives the patient an appointment.

 The same type of communication often occurs by e-mail. This is an opportunity to integrate into Chapter 1 the digital task of sending an e-mail.

Notice several things about the e-mail at the right:

  • Uses the exact language that is used in the chapter.

  • Mirrors the patterns used in the speaking activity.

page.title: Do Your Students Have E-mail Accounts?
page.contents:
Help students who do not already have e-mail accounts by clicking on the button No Email? below.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0380.mp3

Audio transcript


For the next unit activity, create a classroom activity in which your students write an e-mail that aligns closely with the lesson that you use or with Staying Healthy, Chapter 1. If you are engaging in an e-mail activity with Staying Healthy Chapter 1, the e-mail should mirror the telephone conversation in which Fatima Tuma asks for an appointment and describes her symptoms. Use the routines that you normally use in your class to scaffold the activity. You may have students work in pairs to collaboratively craft an e-mail, or you may have students work individually. Depending on the technology environment, your students’ skills, and classroom routines, you can have students write the e-mail on paper first or compose it on a digital device. Include some information about e-mail conventions, as appropriate. Short topics can include, for example, appropriate greetings and closings, issues of privacy, politeness, and the audience.

Have your students send you the e-mail. Respond to each one. As an extension activity, you could have students write short e-mails to other students in the class. On the next page, describe the activity that you design to integrate e-mail into your class, using your own lesson or Staying Healthy.

For students who have e-mail accounts:

  • Create an activity in which your students write an e-mail that is related to the lesson.

  • In Staying Healthy, the e-mail should ask for a medical appointment using similar language to that used in the telephone conversation. In your lesson, the purpose and the language of the e-mail may be different.

  • The e-mail activity can be performed collaboratively in pairs or individually. It can be performed on paper first and then keyboarded in or composed directly on the computer, depending on your students’ abilities and preferences.

  • Have students use their e-mail accounts to send you the e-mail. You should respond to each e-mail.

Use this activity as an opportunity to talk about e-mail conventions, as appropriate. This could include, for example, the audience, politeness, greetings, closings, length, and privacy, depending on students’ level and topic.

page.title: For Students Who Do Not Have E-mail Accounts
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0390.mp3

Audio transcript


Many students will not have e-mail accounts, but it is very important for every student to get an e-mail account. Many resources exist to help students get e-mail accounts, and some will be presented on the next page. An important consideration for you, as a teacher, is to provide a supported environment in which your students work with a helpful person as they learn how to acquire an e-mail account. National research conducted by the Literacy, Language, and Technology Research Group is finding that human support is essential in the development of basic digital skills, including learning how to get and use an e-mail account.

To create the time to work with students, you might pair a more technologically experienced student with a less technologically experienced student. If you routinely use centers to manage the multilevel nature of your class (all adult ELA classes are multilevel in some way, after all), that is a good time to work with a small group of students on the issue of getting an e-mail account.

It is very important for your students to have e-mail accounts. If they do not, it is worth the time and effort that it takes to help them get e-mail accounts and learn to use them.

There are a variety of options to help your students get e-mail accounts. Whatever option you select, be sure to have a person working with the student(s). When learning beginning computer skills, it is very important to have helpful, human support (Jacobs et al., 2014).

Arrange for some time to work with the student(s):

  • Have the student(s) work in pairs with more digitally experienced students.

  • As the teacher, work with a small group while the rest of the class works independently or at centers.

page.title: For Students Who Do Not Have E-mail Accounts
page.contents:
Sze, Lian. “Intro to Email.” DigitalLearn.org. Retrieved from http://digitallearn.org/learn/intro-email.

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License.

Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0400.mp3

Audio transcript


A variety of high-quality resources exist that you can use to work with your students specifically on acquiring and using an e-mail account. The lesson plan provides step-by-step guidance for students and can be used both during and after the e-mail lesson plan. The videos created by digitallearn.org are short and clear.

Here is a lesson plan to help beginning adult ELLs learn how to acquire and use basic e-mail. The lesson plan comes from REEP: The Arlington Education & Employment Program.

Six videos (at right) provide very clear supplemental explanations of the different steps involved in getting and using e-mail:

Lesson 1: What is e-mail?

Lesson 2: Sign up for e-mail.

Lesson 3: Login.

Lesson 4: Open messages and reply.

Lesson 5: Compose and send.

page.title: For Students Who Do Not Have E-mail Accounts— Additional Resources
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_0410.mp3

Audio transcript


Here are two additional resources that can support an e-mail lesson plan.

Passwords 101 is a simple1-minute video that explains what passwords are and how to make good passwords.

Fellows, Larraby. (2011, March 16). “Passwords 101.” http://youtu.be/VzIWURjhrRo. Vermont State Colleges/e-Vermont Community Broadband Project. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 3.0 Unported License.

The Northstar Digital Literacy Assessment e-mail module is helpful practice for students who are learning how to use e-mail.

page.title: Email Lesson Description
page.contents:
You have just learned about various types of email lessons to use with your learners. 

Write a description of your activity.

Will you add an element about e-mail conventions? If so, what convention(s)? 

Share your email activity or your digital form activity with your community of Practice, or with your colleagues on the LINCS discussion forum.

page.title: Integrate Email Activity
page.contents:
After creating an e-mail activity for Staying Healthy or for your lesson, look through the rest of the lessons in your unit or the rest of the chapters in Staying Healthy.

Think about ways to integrate an e-mail activity into every lesson or chapter. 

Not all lessons of the Staying Healthy chapters (or your own lessons) lend themselves to writing an e-mail. Which lesson is the most challenging? Why is it challenging?

Look back at the guidelines for designing digital tasks. What do you think is the best solution?

You have reached the end of this lesson.  You may review any of the content in this lesson using the Lesson Menu on the left of the screen.

If you have finished viewing the lesson, (1) click the NEXT button on this screen to indicate completion in your progress tracker.  Then, (2) return to the home page to select your next activity.  Activities you have completed will be checked off in your progress tracker.
